Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improving Resource Utilization Through Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A novel way to increase resource efficiency is through the use of existing, idle capacity. A Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing System is one where a resource owned by an individual is collectively shared with a group of users. The shared resource can be a physical resource (like a power drill) or a human resource (like the ability to perform a task). By focusing on access over ownership, these Systems allow physical assets to be consumed as services and tasks to be completed by independent individuals. A fundamental characteristic in these Systems is that both supply and demand originate from independent freelance users. Therefore, to match supply with demand in these Systems, a sequential process is common. A central mechanism recommends a set of available alternatives to decentralized users, who then select an alternative (or none at all) based on the user's valuation of the alternatives. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports fundamental research to understand how to effectively match independent individuals through a central mechanism that allows for user selection. The new knowledge gained through this research can lead to Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing Systems that are better understood, designed, and operated, which has the potential to positively impact important systemic societal issues such as transportation congestion, rising population increases, and limited natural resources. As the younger generation is early adopters of these systems, the integration of this research with educational and outreach activities has the potential to excite a new generation of engineers.

The research will improve understanding of how to model and incorporate independent freelance user behavior into an optimization framework and introduce a new class of problems that considers how a central mechanism recommends a set of alternatives to decentralized users for selection. It will develop high fidelity models that incorporate theories and methods from the fields of recommender systems and consumer choice models to describe user preferences and selection behaviors in Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing Systems. An outcome of decentralized user selection is that a 1-to-1 match of supply to demand does not always occur. Thus, a new understanding on how to determine the best way to rectify the demand requests and supply slots that have either been rejected or have duplicate selections will be explored. In doing so, a number of questions about the design of sequential, simultaneous, and hybrid protocols that match decentralized supply with demand will be answered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental characteristic of Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing Systems is that both supply and demand originate from independent freelance users. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supported fundamental research to understand how to mathematically model user selection behavior when autonomous suppliers are recommended a discrete set of potential alternatives for selection in an online platform.  This research is the first to mathematically describe cardinality-based assortment properties of individual selection and the notion of novelty and diversity through a random utility modeling framework.  By defining the observable part of utility as a function of assortment properties, in addition to the attributes of each alternative and those of the user, a new family of random utility models are created.  Perceived representative utility is defined such that a penalty (as a function of assortment cardinality) is introduced when the number of alternatives offered increases beyond a threshold.  These higher fidelity models capture behaviors found empirically in marketing and behavioral research.  This new family of descriptive models - which are extensions to the Multinomial Logit model - capture individual user selection behavior (1) when a trade-off exists between the benefits and the costs of a user considering a set of alternatives; (2) the notion of novelty and diversity by recommending alternatives the user would not likely find herself; and (3) the moderating influence of the viewing medium causing presentation bias. Closed-form expressions for the probability of selection/rejection under four model variants are derived.  Properties of the discrete choice models and no-choice curves are proved. These properties are exploited to recommend optimal assortments to users when the developed discrete choice models are used as inputs to online platform assortment optimization problems.  Novel algorithms are created to solve context based, as well as novelty and diversity assortment optimization problems.  For equal platform utility alternatives, optimal algorithms were developed.  For unequal platform utility alternatives, efficient, near optimal algorithms were developed. Solution approaches were validated using two real world datasets, which required recommender system algorithms to predict missing values.

This research improved our understanding of how to tractably model independent user selection behavior in online platforms.  It is an important step to answering the open research question of how many alternatives to recommend to a particular user? The methods developed can be used by e-commerce and online platforms, as well as by firms interested in scaling personalized services through recommendations. This research can improve the design and operation of Peer-to-Peer Resource Sharing Systems, which have the potential to improve resource efficiency and reduce transportation congestion. This research has excited and recruited a diverse engineering workforce of the future. A female Ph.D. and seven (three female, two African American) undergraduate research projects were directed. This mentorship and research experience led to three of the undergraduate researchers (including an African American and a female student) to pursue graduate school. In addition to submitted papers and academic conference presentations, research results were disseminated to broad audiences, including to (1) practitioners through webinars and professional industry events, (2) policy makers at an on-demand economy workshop, (3) undergraduate students through a keynote presentation at an undergraduate multi-University conference and through new course materials, and (4) future engineering students through recruitment events.
